title: Owen Farrell, the injury gods and Nigel Owens – the heroes and villains of England’s win over Argentina
text:
Owen Farrell struggled with his kicking from the tee (Picture: Getty)

England thrashed Argentina 39-10 to confirm they would not repeat their knockout-stage humiliation of four years ago, although the Pool C job is only half done with France still to come.

The French cannot knock England out but they could still knock them off top spot with a win next weekend – and coach Eddie Jones will have plenty of food for thought after their biggest challenge of the Rugby World Cup so far.

But who showed their best and their worst on a rare, cool night in Tokyo?

Villains

The injury gods

Billy Vunipola has never started 12 England Test matches in a year. Or at least, he hadn’t until now.

This was a watershed moment for the finally fully fit No 8, who coach Jones says he cannot wrap in cotton wool because it does him more harm than good.

Advertisement

Advertisement

But then he tweaked his left ankle, had it heavily strapped, and did not emerge after half-time.

The glib Jones response to a question about him afterwards – ‘I think he had too much Kobe beef, mate’ – will not calm any nerves.

Joe Marler, who covers both prop positions, limped off too with a worrying-looking hamstring problem.

Courtney Lawes

Courtney Lawes has an all-too familiar conversation with the referee (Picture: Getty)

When Courtney Lawes gets it right, he’s one of the most destructive players in the world. When he gets it wrong, the most self-destructive.

Lawes had barely been on the pitch a few minutes when he jumped into a forlorn charge-down and caught Argentine full-back Emiliano Boffelli on the way through.

Having left the ground, he was lucky not to have caught the kicker worse, which would surely have seen Owens reproduce a card.

Owen Farrell

Farrell showed plenty of guile and quality with ball in hand – a beautiful flat pass to Jack Nowell gave him the space to wriggle free – but from the tee he was woeful.

One correspondent suggested that Lavanini’s hit on the captain may have accounted for his four missed first-half kicks but he had already sclaffed one wide by that point.

His next was horribly hooked from the middle of the field and by the time Ben Youngs scored, you had no confidence in Farrell making it one from four.

He finally rectified the situation after the break but admitted afterwards he would be working on his kicking this coming week.

Advertisement

Heroes

Nigel Owens

Nigel Owens did his best to keep the peace in a highly-charged encounter (Picture: Getty)

Not so much a hero for England, but certainly a hero for the game. This was a potential powder-keg of a fixture and World Rugby put their best man on duty.

Owens was at his brilliant best early on – ‘a little bit less talking now lads and a little bit more scrummaging please’ – and was cool, calm and collected when required to dismiss Tomas Lavanini, admitting his initial view was wrong and agreeing with the replay.

Even when it threatened to boil over, as it did on three separate occasions, he managed to keep the two teams away from out-and-out violence. If Wales do not make the final, he must be a shoo-in for the gig.

Sam Underhill

Rightfully given the official Man of the Match award for his tireless efforts at openside , the Bath flanker showed the other side of his game today.

He was aptly described on commentary as a ‘truffle pig’ of a player in recognition of his work at the breakdown, but he unleashed the warthog against Argentina, showing he can be the powerful carrier that some fear a combination of he and Tom Carry lack.

He topped the England tackle count with 16 and produced six powerful carries and an offload.

George Ford

Eddie Jones may always have intended to return to the Ford-Farrell axis, as he did for the first time in a year against Ireland over summer.

Advertisement

If so, it is a stroke of genius. Ford showed all of his play-making abilities against Argentina, his cultured boot ensuring England exploited the space offered by the one-man advantage properly.

🏴󠁧󠁢󠁥󠁮󠁧󠁿 Go Jonny, go, go! England strike back after a fantastic drive. The ball drops wide to May, who makes no mistake#ENGvARG #RWC2019 pic.twitter.com/0SEYeaJHaf — ITV Rugby (@ITVRugby) October 5, 2019

His passing range was brilliant, freezing a defender for the first try, and even punching a score in of his own.

At one point, he even offered a misfiring Owen Farrell his services as a goal-kicker. He was, understandably, rebuffed.
